column1: Table D2.14.3: Selected health outcomes by Indigenous Australians aged 18 and over, reporting access to homelands/traditional country (%), 2018–19

column3: Allowed to visit homelands/ traditional country
column6:
Does not recognise homelands/
traditional country

column1: Has 3 or more long-term health conditions
Ratio three or more/no long-term health condition
Time since last consulted a GP(e)(f)
Saw GP more than 12 months ago(g)
Ratio more than 12 months ago/in last 12 months
Did not have problems accessing services(h)
Ratio had problems/did not have problems
Total number of persons 18+ present at interview
† Estimate has a relative standard error between 25% and 50% and should be used with caution.
‡ Estimate has a relative standard error greater than 50% and is considered too unreliable for general use.
(b) Includes 'don't know whether allowed to visit homelands/traditional country'.

(c) Based on the Kessler-5 (K5) measure of psychological distress. Overall levels of distress are based on how often respondents reported experiencing each feeling. Low/moderate is a score of 5–11. High/very high is a score of 12–25. Totals for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people exclude a small number of people who were not present at interview and for whom responses were provided by a proxy, and persons for whom level of psychological distress was unable to be determined.
(d) Self-reported data consisting of persons reporting a current medical condition which has lasted, or is expected to last, for 6 months or more.

(f) Not comparable to question asked in 2014–15 NATSISS due to change in questions or sequence of questions asked. Some examples of barriers include cost, discrimination services not culturally appropriate and language problems.
(h) Includes those who did not try to access services.

(i) Self-reported data consisting of persons who reported having a disability or restrictive long-term health condition where a limitation, restriction, impairment, disease or disorder has lasted, or is expected to last for six months or more, and restricts everyday activities. Levels of activity limitation (profound, severe, moderate, mild and school/employment restriction only) are based on whether, and how often, a person needs help, has difficulty, or uses aids or equipment with any core activities (self-care, mobility or communication). A person's overall level of core activity limitation is determined by their highest level of limitation in any of these activities.
(j) Includes those that are living with disability but reported no limitation or specific restriction with everyday activities of mobility, self-care and communication.

Note: Percentages add within columns. Cells in this table have been randomly adjusted to avoid the release of confidential data and discrepancies may occur between sums of the component items and totals.
Source: AIHW and ABS analysis of National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Survey 2018–19.
